elements.name: FAQLegalAdvice
elements.title: Where can I get legal advice?
elements.body:
If your income is within the Legal Aid BC's financial guidelines, you may be eligible for a legal aid lawyer to represent you in an application about a protection order. Legal aid is only available to people who meet the financial eligibility criteria and who need an immediate court order to ensure the safety of themselves or their children. To find out if you qualify for free legal advice or representation, contact Legal Aid BC at 1-866-577-2525.

To find a private lawyer or to have a free consultation with a lawyer for up to 30 minutes, contact the Lawyer Referral Service at 1-800-663-1919.

Visit Clicklaw at www.clicklaw.bc.ca/helpmap to find other free and low-cost legal services in your community.

elements.name: explanationQualifying
elements.title:
This service will help you apply for a Provincial Court `Family Law Act Protection Order`.

There is more than one kind of `order` that can protect you and your family. The following questions will help you decide if a `protection order` under the Family Law Act of British Columbia is right for you.

elements.name: unsafe
elements.title: Is someone making you or someone you know feel `unsafe`?

elements.name: EmergencyInstructions
elements.title:
Call 9-1-1 if you, your children and/or someone you know are in immediate danger.

If you are not in immediate danger but are still afraid for your safety, VictimLinkBC can help.

VictimLinkBC is a confidential, multilingual telephone service available 24 hours a day, 7 days a week. Victim service workers can provide crisis support, information and referrals to supports including safety planning, victim services, transition houses and counselling services. Even with a protection order in place, it is a good idea to have a personal safety plan.

Call: 1-800-563-0808 | TTY: 604-875-0885 | Text: 604-863-6381 | Email: VictimLinkBC@bc211.ca

elements.name: explanationPeaceBond
elements.title:
A Family Law Act Protection Order provides protection for an at-risk family member from family violence by another family member. Based on your answer, a Peace Bond is probably the protection order you need. A Peace Bond can protect you from anyone. You can ask the police or RCMP for a Peace Bond, or you can apply for one yourself.

For more information about Peace Bonds, click here:
https://www2.gov.bc.ca/gov/content?id=B9529607F9574FB29E7439847C2808FC

This service cannot help you apply for a Peace Bond.

elements.name: PORConfirmed
elements.title: You appear to meet the requirements to apply for a Provincial Court `Family Law Act Protection Order`. Confirm that this is what you want to do.
elements.description:
You can also apply for a `Peace Bond`. A Peace Bond is another kind of `Protection Order` that covers more situations.

Family Law Act Protection Order Peace Bond
A Family Law Act Protection Order protects a family member from another family member.

To apply for a Family Law Act Protection Order, you will need to tell your story directly to a judge. You can apply on your own or you can hire a lawyer to help. Usually both you, and the person you need protection from, will be in court together. The judge can allow you to make your application without your (ex-)partner in court under special circumstances. 		A Peace Bond protects a person from another person.

To get a Peace Bond, you will need to tell your story to the police, who may then get Crown Counsel to help. Crown counsel apply to the court if they believe a judge is likely to make your order. You can also apply for a Peace Bond without the police or Crown counsel. Your (ex-)partner will have an opportunity to tell their story. You may be called as witness.


Click here for more information about the differences between a Peace Bond and a Provincial Court Family Law Act Protection Order. (This link will open in a new tab.)
